DOC.HEAD: Troops Believe They Almost Caught Him
EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool dispatch from Panama by Steven Komarow of The Associated Press and Robert Kearns of Reuters.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops storming the ``Witch House'' quarters of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega found cigarettes smoking in ashtrays and believe they missed the Panamanian fugitive by minutes, military sources say. The Witch House, one of Noriega's residences, was filled with bizarre black magic paraphernalia. Another of the ousted dictator's quarters was decorated with portraits of Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler, American servicemen told reporters on Thursday. The Witch House is on the sea coast near Panama City, close to several U.S. military bases. Military investigators believe that the house may have been booby-trapped and would not allow reporters and photographers inside until it could be made safe, said Gen. John Huston. Soldiers on the scene some six hours after the fighting started said they thought Noriega may have made a narrow escape. ``The cigarettes were still smoking in the ashtray and the women left their purses, which no woman would ever usually do,'' said a soldier familiar with the house. Troops who saw the house spread word that the room in which the purses were found was apparently devoted to the occult, with signs of animal entrails and ``vats of blood,'' the soldier said. Military officials could not immediately confirm the soldier's account. He declined to permit use of his name. Sgt. 1st Class Joseph Torregrossa said there were some bizarre trappings in Noriega's private office in the No. 8 building of Panama's military barracks at Fort Amador. ``When we went inside, there were all of these expensive prints, but he also had a portrait of Adolf Hitler and a lot of expensive weapons, mostly automatic,'' Torregrossa said. ``He had German Lugers, Israeli Uzis (and) all sorts of real sophisticated stuff.''
